content:
the Michigan Daily

One hundred and thirtythree years of editorial freedom

BAGHDAD AP  Suspected Sunni Arab gunmen killed  policemen yesterday including  in one attack in the predominantly Shiite southern city of Basra signaling the possible start of an intensified insurgent campaign against Iraqs predominantly Shiite Muslim security forces PERIOD

Political tension deepened in Baghdad when Vice President Tariq alHashemi the countrys highestranking Sunni politician threatened to resign if Prime Minister Nouri alMaliki did not act quickly to eradicate two feared Shiite militias PERIOD

AlMaliki a Shiite depends heavily on the backing of the two Shiite political parties that run the militias and has resisted American pressure to eradicate the private armies  the Mahdi Army of radical cleric Muqtada alSadr and the Badr Brigade the military wing of Iraqs biggest Shiite political bloc the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq PERIOD

Shiite gunmen especially those of the Mahdi Army are deeply involved in the sectarian killings that have brutalized Baghdad and central Iraq for months PERIOD

Police have been targeted throughout the insurgency in an effort to destabilize the U.S.supported government but the number of attacks Sunday was a sharp stepup in attacks aimed at security services PERIOD

The surge in violence also comes amid U.S PERIOD efforts to bring Sunni insurgents into a reconciliation process and a public squabble with alMaliki over a timeline for crushing the Shiite militias and moving forward with measures to soothe the disaffected Sunni minority PERIOD

Thirtythree people in all were slain across Iraq yesterday in a second day of rising violence that ended a fiveday lull in attacks after the end Muslims holy month of Ramadan PERIOD

Officials also found  bodies some of them decapitated the latest victims of sectarian reprisal killings that have soared since Sunni bombers destroyed a Shiite shrine in Samarra north of the capital Feb PERIOD  PERIOD
